text.text_translated:
Carol Dweck works at Stanford.  
She gave ten‑year‑old children a task.  
The task was a little too hard.  
One group liked the hard task.  
They said they liked the challenge.  
They thought they could learn more4 later.  
They believed they could become better.  
They had a growth mindset.  
A growth mindset means they think they can improve with effort.  
The other group felt the task judged how smart they were.  
They said they did not do well.  
They thought they could not become better.  
They had a fixed mindset.  
A fixed mindset means they think their ability cannot change.  
Some children said they might copy answers next time.  
Others looked for another child who did worse.  
That helped them feel better.

best_attempt.text_translated:
Carol Dweck works at Stanford.  
She gave ten‑year‑old children a task.  
The task was a little too hard.  
One group liked the hard task.  
They said they loved the challenge.  
They thought they could learn more later.  
They believed they could become better.  
This shows they think they can improve.  
The other group felt the task tested their intelligence.  
They said they had failed.  
They thought they could not become better.  
This shows they think they cannot improve.  
Some children said they might cheat later.  
Others looked for another child who did worse.  
That helped them feel better about themselves.
